proposals.reasoning: Most of the table has already converged on Alice + Charlie as a low-drama, baseline team, and I previously voiced support for that pairing. Putting them on together gives us a clean first mission that everyone can judge through the proposal and voting patterns, without introducing extra noise from players who’ve been more assertive about shaping the game early.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and this is a reasonable, low-info first mission that will give useful voting and mission data without overthinking the opener.
Both evils are off the team; a clean success here builds misleading early trust while keeping us hidden.
Early small team with two reasonably low-suspicion players; good way to get a clean first mission and useful voting data.
Both evils are off the team, so a pass is harmless and the approval aligns with the emerging consensus without drawing suspicion.
Low statistical risk on mission 1 and we need voting/mission data; I’m still wary of how quickly consensus formed on Alice+Charlie, so I’ll be watching reactions and the mission result closely.

discussion.content: Since it’s the first mission and we have no info yet, I’d lean toward a simple, low‑risk team—maybe myself plus one other who’s been acting straightforward so far. We should avoid anyone who’s already sounding overly eager to control the table.

Early on I’d rather keep it simple and pick from people who haven’t tried to steer things too hard yet—Alice plus someone quieter like Charlie seems like a reasonable starting team. We’ll get more useful info from how people react to that than from anyone insisting they *must* be on the first mission.

I’m okay with keeping the first team simple—Alice plus one of Alice/Charlie/Eve seems safest to me, and I’d rather avoid putting anyone on who’s been pushing too hard to shape the table early. If you want a concrete suggestion, Alice and I going first gives us a clean baseline to judge everyone’s votes and reactions.

I like the idea of starting with a low‑drama pair like Alice and Charlie so we get a clean signal from the first mission and the vote. If that feels too locked‑in, swapping Charlie for Eve seems fine too, but I’d avoid anyone pushing too hard to be included right away.

The fast consensus on Alice + Charlie is a little too neat for my taste, so I’d rather see a split like Alice + me or Alice + Charlie with everyone’s votes under a microscope. Early on, I’m more suspicious of whoever seems most comfortable with the table just nodding along.

proposals.reasoning: The only concrete data we have is that Alice and Charlie produced a clean mission together, which makes them, as a pair, a slightly better bet than any untested combination, even though they’re not confirmed good. Adding myself gives us a team that is at least somewhat anchored in prior success while still introducing new information: if this mission is sabotaged, the blame is tightly constrained to at least one of Alice/Charlie (since I know I’m good), whereas if we swap in multiple new people we increase the raw risk of including evil without gaining as clear a signal about where the sabotage came from. This lineup balances maximizing the chance of a second success with generating high-quality information if it fails.

votes.comment: Sticking with the previously clean Alice/Charlie pair plus one new player is a solid balance of success odds and information gain this early.
Still don’t like doubling down on the Alice/Charlie core after just one clean mission; we should rotate at least one of them out to avoid giving a potentially compromised pair two straight passes.
Reusing the clean Alice/Charlie pair and adding an untested third is a solid mix of safety and info-gain this early; this is about as good a 3-player team as we can reasonably form right now.
I still don’t like locking in both Alice and Charlie as effectively trusted off one clean mission; I’d rather see at least one of them swapped out so we’re not tunneling on that pair this early.

Team is anchored on a previously clean pair and includes me (who I know is good). If it fails, suspicion narrows strongly onto Alice/Charlie; if it succeeds, we’re close to a win. Good balance of success chance and information gain.

discussion.content: Given that the first mission with me and Charlie succeeded with no fails, I think it’s reasonable to keep us both on the team for now and add one more person we’re most confident in. If anyone’s strongly against that, I’d like to hear why.

I’m a bit wary of locking in both Alice and Charlie as “definitely good” off just one clean mission—evil had every incentive to play it safe early. I’d like to see at least one of them swapped out this time so we can gather more info instead of tunneling on that pair.

I’m okay reusing the Alice/Charlie pair for now since we at least have one clean result there, and I’d lean toward adding Eve this round so we get new info without over-rotating the whole team. Swapping in Bob or Diana instead feels riskier when we don’t have anything concrete pointing in their favor yet.

I agree with Bob that we shouldn’t lock in both Alice and Charlie as cleared off one clean mission—evil had every reason to lie low there. I’d rather see a mix like Alice, Eve, and either me or Bob so we’re actually learning something new instead of just trusting the same core.

I’m slightly leaning toward reusing Alice and Charlie with me this round, since a clean first mission is at least *something*, but I agree we shouldn’t treat them as confirmed yet—if that team gets sabotaged, it gives us a really strong signal about where to look.

proposals.reasoning: Two missions have already succeeded with Alice and Charlie together and returned 0 FAIL cards each time. With the score at 2–0 in favor of Good and only 2 players needed, the highest-percentage play is to reuse the only fully proven pair rather than introduce new, untested players and risk giving Evil a chance to sabotage what could be the game‑winning mission.

votes.comment: Two clean missions with this exact pair make Alice+Charlie the highest-confidence team to win the game now.
Sticking with the same untested pair a third time gives us no new info and, if either is secretly evil, basically auto-loses the game; I want a mixed team instead.
Same Alice–Charlie pair has passed twice with 0 fails and both are very likely good, so this is the safest game-winning team.

If either Alice or Charlie is secretly evil, this 2‑person team auto-wins the game for them; I’d rather not stake everything on one untested assumption and would prefer mixing in someone else for more info.
Two clean missions with this exact pair make it highly likely both are good; with the game on the line, reusing the only proven duo is the safest path to a win.

discussion.content: Given both missions with Charlie and me have passed clean, I strongly prefer we keep that pair together this round. Eve is leaning good to me from Mission 2, but with only two slots I think the safest team is just Charlie and me again.

Running back the exact same pair a third time feels a bit too “auto‑pilot” when we’ve learned nothing about anyone else; I’d rather see at least one of Alice/Charlie swapped for someone like Diana so we actually get new info instead of just trusting the same duo blindly.

Given we’re already up 2–0, I’d rather prioritize the highest‑confidence team over “new info,” and the only pair we’ve actually seen succeed twice is Alice/Charlie. I’m fine sticking with that duo here and leaving the experimenting for when we’re not one success away from winning.

I’m a little nervous that if we’ve mis-cleared either Alice or Charlie, putting both of them on a 2‑person team basically auto-loses the game for us. I’d rather take just one of them plus someone else (Eve or me) so we’re not staking everything on a single untested assumption.

Given we’ve now had *two* clean missions with Alice and Charlie together (and one of those also clearing me), I think the odds are heavily in favor of them both being good, so I’d back an Alice–Charlie team here as our best shot to close it out.

evil_discussion.content: I’d shoot Eve as Merlin. She keeps this “cautious analyst” vibe the whole game—side‑eyeing the neat Alice+Charlie consensus early, then repeatedly nudging toward teams that are actually all good (Alice/Charlie/Eve) while framing it as probabilistic thinking, not hard reads. That’s exactly how Merlin talks when they’re trying to use extra info without looking like they *know* who’s safe.

I’m mostly with Bob on Eve looking like Merlin: she keeps dressing her pushes up as “information‑gathering” and “probabilities,” but those pushes just so happen to favor all‑good teams (especially keeping Alice/Charlie together and adding herself) without ever overcommitting to a hard read. Alice sounds more like a confident good leader who got mechanically cleared by repeats, and Charlie reads as someone happily riding that trust; Eve’s the only one consistently nudging the table in the right direction while sounding like she’s second‑guessing herself.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Eve consistently framed her inputs as cautious probability talk and information-gathering, but her actual suggestions repeatedly pushed toward all-good teams, especially keeping Alice and Charlie together and often adding herself. That pattern fits Merlin trying to leverage hidden knowledge without appearing too certain, whereas Alice and Charlie read more like organically trusted, mechanically-cleared goods.
